SECRETARY'S ANNUAL REPORT TO COUNCIL for the year 1998/9


The present membership of Council is as follows:

President
Professor Michael Glazer
Vice-President
Dr Frank Allen
Secretary
Dr Hilary Muirhead
Treasurer
Dr Steve Maginn

Group Representatives
(Biological Structures)
Dr Leo Brady
(Chemical Crystallography)
Dr Sandy Blake
(Industrial)
Professor Christopher Frampton
(Physical Crystallography)
Dr Chick Wilson
Members
Professor Guy Orpen
Mr David Taylor
Vacancy

Co-opted Professor Michael Woolfson FRS

Ex officio
(Exhibition Co-ordinator)
Professor Paul Barnes
(Newsletter Editor & Webmaster
Mrs Kate Crennell
(Administrative & Membership Secretary)
Dr Stephanie Harris

The Council has met twice during the year: during the IUCr Meeting in Glasgow and at Birkbeck College, London in October 1999. At the AGM in Glasgow the Vice-President and the Secretary were re-elected to serve for a further two years. Mr David Taylor was elected as an Ordinary Member of Council and there is one vacancy for an Ordinary member of Council. The changes in the Constitution mean that, from this year's AGM, members of Council will be elected for three year terms instead of two year terms. At the Council Meeting Professor Michael Woolfson was co-opted to serve on Council until 2002.

In 1999 four excellent quarterly issues of Crystallography News were published. The coloured covers are very attractive and the Newsletter made a small profit. The British Library has assigned us an ISSN number for the newsletter (ISSN 1467-2790). The Newsletter has published full accounts of all the events mentioned in this report and the Council thanks the Editor for her efforts in compiling the Newsletter, as well as for the substantial advertisement revenue generated. Kate Crennell also maintains the BCA Website on the Internet; a snapshot of the Website in July was copied to the IUCrXVIII Congress CD-ROM.

The IUCr Congress in Glasgow was a great success. It was the largest IUCr Congress ever held with more than 2600 participants. Council would like to congratulate Chris Gilmore, who ran the local organisation, and Judith Howard, who produced a scientific programme of high quality and variety.

During the year there were several meetings and workshops. All four groups have held meetings, including ones on 'Making and Studying Protein Complexes' (University of Oxford), 'Molecular Geometry using methods Complementary to Crystallography' (University of Manchester), 'Industrial Forum' (Coventry) and 'Pushing the Limits of Powder Diffraction' (RAL).

The Seventh Intensive Course in X-ray Structure Analysis was held at Durham. This was the largest school yet with, 83 participants, including many from abroad. The Sixth Summer School in Protein Crystallography was held in St Andrews. It is hoped that this school will be run every year with venues alternating which will be responsible for European Crystallographic Meetings.

Membership is healthy and many young crystallographers have received BCA bursaries to attend meetings and conferences, both in the UK and world-wide. Frank Allen (with Chick Wilson as alternate) represents the BCA on the European Crystallographic Association (ECA). Frank is a member of the ECA Council, which will be responsible for European Crystallographic Meetings.

We are looking forward to the BCA Spring Meeting at the Edinburgh Conference Centre, Heriot-Watt University. The Plenary Session is on Refinement and the local organiser is Georgina Rosair. The next BCA meeting will be at Reading 7-10 April 2001.

Hilary Muirhead
